greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest odd number k such that sigma(x) = k has exactly n solutions.
comment: Note that sigma(x) is odd iff x is in A028982 (numbers of the form m^2 or 2m^2 for m > 0).
The least common divisor of the first 13 terms is k = 63540409508528099686942221. Checking the divisors of k to see if they give an upper bound for some a(n) gives these upper bounds:
All these listed upper bounds are divisors of 12302819034343122006137404371659222028537. No more divisors of this number are an upper bound for any n.
This method doesn't give a stronger lower bound except that it tells us that a new upper bound for some term is no divisor of k. (End)
link: Max Alekseyev, Computing the Inverses, their Power Sums, and Extrema for Euler's Totient and Other Multiplicative Functions, Journal of Integer Sequences 19 (2016), Article 16.5.2
David A. Corneth, PARI program, partially written by Max Alekseyev
example: For n = 3, sigma(x) = 347529 has exactly three solutions x = 164836, 203522, 239121.
mathematica: Needs["Statistics`DataManipulation`"]; nn=10^6; t1=DivisorSigma[1,Range[nn]^2]; t2=DivisorSigma[1,2*Range[nn/Sqrt[2]]^2]; t=Join[t1,t2]; {u,v}=Transpose[Sort[Frequencies[t]]]; Table[p=Position[u,i,1,1][[1,1]]; v[[p]], {i,Length[Union[u]]}]
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, Oct 02 2006
